Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research and RUI: Auxin Fluxes in the Arabidopsis Root Apex--a Combined Experimental and Computational Approach
Award.AbstractNarration: Abstract: Hidden by soil and often ignored, the root is vital to the growing plant, exploring the soil to get water and nutrients and providing anchorage. Root form and function is regulated by the plant hormone auxin, which is produced and transported by specialized protein families in the plant. The activity of these proteins is understood in broad outline, but quantitative aspects remain unclear. The research goals of the project aim to advance knowledge of auxin transport by combining experimental and computational approaches. The experimental approaches of this multidisciplinary project include high-resolution measurements of the movement of auxin itself, as well as of the propagation of auxin-mediated responses, such as cell growth. The experiments will use the species Arabidopsis thaliana, the "fruit fly" of plant biology. The nearly transparent roots are a significant advantage for microscope work, and the available storehouse of auxin-related mutants is second to none. The computational aspect of the project will refine AuxSim, a model under development by Kramer that is already recognized as a powerful computational tool for auxin transport. The refined model and experimental results will fill in several blanks in the flow-chart for auxin transport within the root. This will synergize with contemporary efforts to understand the molecular biology of auxin action, and may also help applied efforts to enhance agricultural productivity by improving root efficiency. AuxSim will be made freely available. The award will partner undergraduates at Simon's Rock and UMass Amherst, and will provide training that is both biologically rigorous and computationally rich, a combination increasingly considered essential for tomorrow's workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Collaborative Research and RUI: Auxin Fluxes in the Arabidopsis Root Apex--a Combined Experimental and Computational Approach

 Project Outcomes Report

            This project is a collaboration between the PI, Tobias Baskin (University of Massachusetts-Amherst) and a second PI, Eric Kramer (Bard College at Simon’s Rock). Baskin is an experimental biologist in the area of plant physiology; Kramer is a theoretical physicist interested in molecular transport. The project is led by Kramer, and reflects an attempt to improve our understanding of how molecules move within the plant by using empirical data to verify theoretical models.

          Specifically, the project is concerned with the molecule, indole acetic acid. This low molecular weight solute is famous as being the plant hormone, auxin. This hormone plays a role in nearly every aspect of plant development but we do not understand how this molecule moves between cells. It is known that a specific system exists dedicated to moving the hormone, but many features of the system remain to be figured out.

            Our project has had two major research outcomes that involved work at the bench (please see the report for Kramer’s award, IOS-0815453, for an account of outcomes that are strictly computational). First, we were able to provide missing information regarding the effect of plasmodesmata. These are channels between cells that directly connect the cytoplasm of one cell to the next. Previous researchers had characterized plasmodesmata by finding out how large a molecule can be and still make it through. This limit turned out to be around 1000 Daltons, which is larger than most metabolites and nutrients. Our project was able to measure the capacity of the channels, namely how many molecules can move through per unit time. We found that this capacity was about ten-times larger than previously assumed. This means that plant cells are quite effectively connected to one another, at least as far as small molecules are concerned, and has implications for the machinery needed specifically to transport auxin. This work was published in Plant Physiology in 2011.

            The second research outcome has been to measure how much auxin can cross the membrane of a plant cell per time. The passage of auxin into the cell is known to be facilitated by a specific carrier protein present in the plasma membrane, but it is not known to what extent auxin can enter the cell by other means. We compared rates of entry between cells that have the carrier and others that are similar but lack the carrier, thanks to a mutation. We found that the carrier is responsible for almost all of the movement of auxin into the cell. This fact improves our ability to predict correctly how and where auxin is able to move through a plant body. A paper describing these results is being written.

            A post-doctoral research fellow, Heidi Rutschow, worked on the project and is continuing her career by applying methods she developed to a different system. Several undergraduate students worked on the project. One of them enjoyed the research experience to such an extent that she decided to pursue an advanced degree on the hormone auxin; she is currently a Ph. D. student at the University of Leeds, UK (she is an American citizen but chose to work with a leading auxin biologist at Leeds after hearing him speak at UMass).
